Articles.Content:
I've been wondering for a while for how long do people keep their savegames. Some start a new savegame every version, which is quite often (thx Squad), others, like myself, like to continue playing one ad infinitum, in my case mostly because of the aspect of the savegame representing the history of my program, my time spent with the game. For this reason I also have debris set to unlimited an happily continue to collect more of it (nearly 300 atm), building a true space graveyard.

So, provided he was born in a rocket the first time you launched, how old is your oldest Jeb? Mine's a little over 80 years old in my current savegame. I'll probably have a great party in 100AJ before finally sending him off to the Sun to be cremated in the most spectacular coffin anyone's ever seen and start a new savegame then.

I deleted mine.

I get rid of all of the orange suits every time in my careers. Then I turn permadeath on and use Final Frontier to track the accomplishments of the rest of my Kerbal.

I deleted mine.

I get rid of all of the orange suits every time in my careers. Then I turn permadeath on and use Final Frontier to track the accomplishments of the rest of my Kerbal.

I had that idea too but then I remembered that I'd probably abuse quicksaves anyway so there's no need for that. Anyway the point was how old was your oldest savegame.
My big 3 are dead in my career save. They didn't even live to be 1.
About a hundred years by now, I think.

2 days on my arm save, the only time i will timewarp is getting to manuver nodes or Jool missions.

In before Brotoro.
He's around 80 days old, trying to get science back to Kerbin by "getting out and pushing"
Mine has aged about 4 years since last October, when I started the save. *sigh* never missing a launch window and all that stuff...
